bibliography_entries.line_html: The Greek text of the Protevangelium exists in a daunting ca. 140 MSS. Most of these are catalogued in two doctoral dissertations from Duke University: Boyd Lee Daniels, “The Greek Manuscript Tradition of the Protevangelium Jacobi” (1956); and George T. Zervos, “Prolegomena to a Critical Edition of the Genesis Marias (Protevangelium Jacobi): The Greek Manuscripts” (1986). A definitive Greek critical edition of the text does not yet exist. Rather than list all of the MSS here, I present below the major Greek editions, in chronological order, with reference to the most significant MSS from which they draw.
bibliography_entries.line_text: The Greek text of the Protevangelium exists in a daunting ca. 140 MSS. Most of these are catalogued in two doctoral dissertations from Duke University: Boyd Lee Daniels, “The Greek Manuscript Tradition of the Protevangelium Jacobi” (1956); and George T. Zervos, “Prolegomena to a Critical Edition of the Genesis Marias (Protevangelium Jacobi): The Greek Manuscripts” (1986). A definitive Greek critical edition of the text does not yet exist. Rather than list all of the MSS here, I present below the major Greek editions, in chronological order, with reference to the most significant MSS from which they draw.

bibliography_entries.line_html: De Strycker, Émile. La Forme la plus ancienne du Protévangile de Jacques. SH 33. Bruxelles: Société des Bollandistes, 1961. The most extensive critical edition to date, which employs the Bodmer V MS as a base text and incorporates various Armenian, Coptic, Ethiopic, Georgian, Greek, and Latin witnesses.
bibliography_entries.line_text: De Strycker, Émile. La Forme la plus ancienne du Protévangile de Jacques. SH 33. Bruxelles: Société des Bollandistes, 1961. The most extensive critical edition to date, which employs the Bodmer V MS as a base text and incorporates various Armenian, Coptic, Ethiopic, Georgian, Greek, and Latin witnesses.

bibliography_entries.line_html: Hock, Ronald F. The Infancy Gospels of James and Thomas. SB 2. Santa Rosa: Polebridge, 1995. A “hybrid” critical edition that draws from Tischendorf and, more significantly, de Strycker. Hock also incorporates P.Oxy. 3524, a sixth-century papyrus containing the penultimate verse and the epilogue of the Protevangelium. Hock’s edition is probably the most frequently cited in modern scholarly work on the Protevangelium.
